In northeastern Thailand, rabies infection is on the rise

Dr. Thawichai of the 9th Disease Prevention and Management Office revealed on February 9 that rabies infections have been on the rise in northeastern Thailand over the past few months, with a total of 74 people infected.
So far this year (since October last year to September this year), 74 people have been confirmed to have rabies in the northeastern provinces of Surin and Buri Ram.
All of them had received rabies vaccine in the past.
The doctor is calling on people to get vaccinated against rabies along with their pets, and to avoid touching the saliva of animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies can be contracted not only from dogs but also from cats and bats.
Although almost 100% of people who are infected with rabies die, death can be prevented by vaccination before the onset of symptoms.

FUJI Placement and Accident Prevention System Development Experiment with Own Vehicles | Mid-Japan Economist Economic Information in Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

FUJI (headquarters in Chiryu City), which manufactures and sells electronic parts mounting robots and work machines, has begun developing a system to prevent "left-behind" items in cars, such as children being left behind.
A system that attaches a human sensor to the inside of a car to detect movement, and sends a notification to a phone or chat.
Currently, we are conducting a demonstration experiment using our own company's shuttle vehicles.
In the midst of accidents caused by being left behind, we will protect the safety of children.

Currently, the company is conducting a trial experiment using two vehicles that are used to transport children to and from the English conversation after school program "teracoya THANK (TeraCoya SANK)" that is operated by the company in Chiryu City.
A motion sensor that detects movement of people based on the temperature difference between people and their surroundings is installed in three locations on the ceiling of the vehicle.
If the vehicle's engine is turned off and the doors are closed, and if a certain amount of time has passed, and if movement is detected, then a warning notification will be sent automatically.
By linking the engine and door status with information, it is possible to prevent false detection as much as possible.
The notification of the warning is sent through the cloud.
You can call the number you registered in advance, or display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
It is possible to register multiple addresses, and it is designed to prevent mistakes such as overlooking.
The field test will continue until the end of February.
Kamiya Isoroku, chief of the 2nd section of the Innovation Promotion Department, pointed out, "During the experiment, we have also noticed peripheral issues that are not related to the system."
For example, it has been able to pick up various issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment where drivers can concentrate on driving.
We will put our efforts into expanding the solution.
The development of the "placement prevention system" was triggered by a series of accidents in which school buses were left unattended nationwide.
A member with a young child asked if there was anything that could be done to protect the safety of children.
By using the know-how cultivated through FA (Factory Automation) related business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors, to manage information, they decided to develop the system.
FUJI's removal prevention system is sold on its ease of use.
The sensor can be installed by simply pinning it to the ceiling.
Because it can be easily attached to the moving vehicle, it reduces the hurdle to introduction and aims to popularize it.
In the future, we will also consider productization while seeking cooperation with nurseries and kindergartens.

Chocolate sales for Valentine's Day at Seibu Fukui Store in Fukui City, Fukui Prefecture, after a three-year hiatus

As Valentine's Day approaches on February 14th, the price of chocolate at retail stores is rising due to the rise in the price of raw materials and packaging materials, and sales of high-priced chocolate for personal use and gifts to family and friends are going well.
In small shops and confectionery stores in Fukui Prefecture, they are trying to attract customers with products that emphasize local color, high quality, and attention to materials.

This year's trend is "there are many products that emphasize the material or the packaging to give a sense of luxury. As a consumer trend, it seems that people are buying them for themselves and their families and enjoying the ratio of food to food."

The roadside station "Rennyo no Sato Awara" in Yoshizaki, Awara City, Fukui Prefecture, which is currently under construction, will open on April 22.

It is expected to attract about 360,000 users per year as a new regional revitalization and tourist hub in the northern area of the city, with the opening of Hokuriku Shinkansen Awara Onsen Station in spring 2024.
The main food and beverage facility at the station will be a steel frame construction with a total floor space of 975m².
The overall area of the roadside station, including the parking lot and the Nagisa Children's Park, is 8137 square meters.

Electric bicycles can be rented, and there is also a shower room.
There are two parking lots that can accommodate a total of 66 vehicles (including 3 for the disabled).

They will also be selling processed foods such as bento and zensai, as well as agricultural and horticultural products such as seedlings and trees.
In the souvenir corner, in addition to displaying and selling works by Mori Art Museum resident artists, they will also sell confectionery, alcohol, and traditional crafts.

A cat-shaped robot that serves meals at "Iwasa Aged Ginisukan Bon Fukui Station Front Store".
Fukui Prefecture Fukui City Oda 2-chome, where customers love the cat's cute expressions and the like.
In the food service industry in Fukui Prefecture, which is suffering from a shortage of workers, the trend of introducing robots that deliver meals to the table is spreading.
In addition to helping with the reduction of staff and the prevention of coronavirus infections, the robot's cute expressions have been well received by families.
A voice from restaurant owners and related parties says, "It is difficult for local restaurants to secure employees and part-timers, so I think that delivery robots will become even more popular."
"Jin, Jin, Jingisukan" (a Mongolian dish).
A robot with a cat's face on the screen, which moves smoothly through the restaurant while playing light music, is used to deliver food.
When it arrives at the table, it says, "I've brought your order, meow."
In August 2022, "Iwashima Yakumon Jingisukan Bon Fukui Ekimae" in Daito 2-chome, Fukui City, introduced a cat-shaped food delivery robot.
When a customer places an order, the robot, which is waiting near the kitchen, will load the food onto its tray and autonomously move to the table with the table number displayed on the screen.
It is equipped with AI (artificial intelligence) voice function, and reacts when touched by customers, and the expression of the cat face on the screen is also rich.
The "Bonta Group" that operates this restaurant and others has introduced the delivery robot at two restaurants including this one.

The ratio of labor costs to sales is usually around 30%, but it has been reduced to 21-22% by the introduction of the robot.

The robots also have the role of collecting dishes that have been eaten by customers, which contributes to the efficiency of cleaning up, and adds, "It's also good for families and children, and it's good for advertising."
The "Rokkan Hoshiyama Fukui" restaurant, which serves grilled meat and hot pot, located in Shinboucho, Fukui City, also introduced a food delivery robot in August 2022.

The president of the company, Hoshiyama Eifuku, who runs the Sonzan store, said, "Even if we recruit employees and part-timers, they don't come. I thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the shortage of workers," and talked about the background of the introduction.
At the Fukui store, the employees and robots are divided into zones, with the employees handling the serving area and the robots handling the delivery area.
The rental fee for the robot is said to be the same as the wage of one part-time worker.
In order to reduce the number of employees, the restaurant is also considering the introduction of a tablet ordering system and self-service.

According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, the effective recruitment ratio for the job category of "customer service" in restaurants and the like was 6.94 times in December 2022, and it is a job category with a high shortage of workers.

The person in charge of the network system (Kawamachi Chuo 2-chome, Fukui) that acts as the sales agent for the delivery robots said, "The labor shortage in restaurants in the prefecture has become more serious due to the impact of the coronavirus, and there has been a lot of inquiries about the introduction of robots."
President Hoshiyama commented, "I think that it will become even more difficult to secure employees at suburban stores in the future, and that delivery robots will become more popular."
【评论】越前町制作了“期望的城镇”的结束语，向期望的市民分发。

The previous year, the town issued a "caregiver's handbook" that included a list of procedures and forms needed when a family member passes away, as well as a family tree, and many people came to receive it for their own use.

In various parts of the prefecture, lectures on how to write an ending note and how to organize one's belongings before death are being held, and it seems that "shuukatsu" has become firmly rooted in the minds of the people.
The ending note of Echizen Town is 35 pages.

It starts with a chapter on looking back on one's life, followed by the current state of health and assets, hopes for future care and end-of-life medical care, and wishes regarding funerals and graves.
There is also a space to write down things you want to do in your remaining life and a space to write messages to important people.
Although it says that it takes 35 pages to write, you don't have to fill out every page.
What do you want to leave behind for your family and the people around you?
The most important thing is to make the purpose clear.
You can start writing from the place where you can write, and there are various notes for sale at bookstores and so on that are suitable for the purpose.
The term "job hunting" was born in 2009, and the term "job hunting" was born.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people were confronted with the reality that "death comes suddenly," and it is said that more people are preparing for their final days and end of life.
It's been more than 10 years since then.
The novel coronavirus pandemic that swept the world is still not over.
Prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and electricity prices this winter have risen to an unthinkable level.
On the other hand, wages have not risen to match the current high inflation, causing many people to worry about the future.
On the other hand, funeral expenses and care expenses that were once shared by relatives and friends are now rare in the age of only children.
Also, while life expectancy has increased significantly in recent years, the risk of dementia and the need for nursing care increases as one gets older, which is a dilemma.
I want to keep in mind that the background of the funeral not ending in a flash but settling in is the rise of social unrest.
After all, who wouldn't want to avoid putting an undue burden on their partner or children?
The phrase "the end of life as you wish" is a popular keyword, but it should not be too lonely.
It's not about secretly writing down your wishes, but rather talking to your family once and preparing calmly for that time.

Prime Minister Kishida Fumio (second from right) and Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology Nagaoka Keiko (third from right) pose for a commemorative photo at a primary school visited by the delegation.
At the graduation ceremony, it is not necessary to wear a mask for children and teachers in principle = February 10, Toda City, Saitama Prefecture
On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that it is the basic policy that children do not wear masks at graduation ceremonies.
The headmaster of a large school said, "It's difficult to keep a wide distance between students, and I'm wondering how to deal with it. Some students are also worried about taking off their masks."
According to reports on the wearing of masks at graduation ceremonies, the topic has also been raised among teachers.
On the other hand, a principal of a primary school said, "If the government decides, it will be a form without wearing masks. If it is not singing, it is not practically possible."

At this year's graduation ceremony, there are also moves to ease the countermeasures at some schools in the prefecture, such as allowing students who had been absent to participate and resuming the graduation choir.

In the prefecture, the prefectural high school is scheduled to hold the ceremony on the first week of March, and the public elementary and junior high schools are scheduled to hold the ceremony on the same week.
The prefectural and municipal education committees are waiting for official notification from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology to make a decision on how to respond.
In addition, there were cautious voices regarding the Ministry of Education's decision to not require the use of masks in all school activities starting this spring.

A primary school principal said, "Suddenly telling children to not wear masks will leave them confused. If we decide to make it optional, the number of children who are coughing and sneezing will naturally increase."

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10 that from April, it will not require the wearing of masks in school education activities, in line with the government's new guidelines on mask wearing.
Masks will be optional in choir, physical education classes, and club activities.

For the current academic year, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology will request that schools follow the current health management manual for infection prevention measures, and will inform the Education Committee and school sites of the points to note after April.

Graduation ceremonies for elementary, junior high, and high schools, as well as universities, will be held in the 2022 academic year with measures such as ventilation in place, and it is expected that graduates, teachers, and students who attend will not wear masks as a basic rule.

The NPO organization "Kokoro no Kagaku Shuin / Editing Bureau" self-published the book "Dear Prime Minister, the "Breakwater of Life" from Tōjinbō".
This is the 10th book we have published under the title "Dear Prime Minister, a Breakwater for Life, from Tōjinbō".
It has been picked up by newspapers all over the country, and we have received many letters of thanks from readers.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share with everyone the contents of the "social and structural" environmental problems that I have heard directly from those who have attempted suicide, and to express the wish to create a "society where people can live comfortably".

We have been patrolling the water's edge in Tōjinbō, Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months, in order to prevent suicide, and have been continuing to support the discovery and protection of suicide planners and their reintegration into society.

This book is a compilation of the problems that have been heard from 784 people (2/6 currently) who have been protected so far, and as a request to the Prime Minister of the Cabinet, it calls for the following seven items to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there is a mountain of "human rights violations".
(3) Those who commit suicide are victims of organized crime in the social and structural sense.
(4) Administrative agencies treat citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "strangers" and neglect them.
(5)Even if people with mental illnesses such as depression commit suicide, they are treated as "accidents".
(6) The "duty of care" for suicide high-risk areas is being forgotten and commercialism is running rampant.
(7) The teachings of new religious groups that cannot be scientifically proven are deceptive and threatening to extort money by claiming that they will bring curses in the future.
It is necessary to expose and exclude the religious organizations that commit these crimes of "fraud and extortion".

Therefore, we have received many comments from those who have purchased this book, such as "I was moved by the strong mental attitude of those who are involved in this activity," "The former police officer's appearance is a model for police officers," and "A bodhisattva who lives like a member of our own family even though he is a stranger," and we would like to introduce one of these comments here.
I was moved to tears when I saw the photo in the newspaper article and thought, "What must they be thinking...".
I've heard that the number of people committing suicide due to being pushed into a corner by the coronavirus pandemic is increasing.
It's really sad.
Everyone is like that.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can live our lives with gratitude for the lives we have been given.
I felt gratitude and respect for the staff who have been working tirelessly to help people who are suffering so much that they feel like they want to die.
I think this activity is mentally and physically exhausting, but please continue to ask for help in the future as well.
thank you.
kashiko
I hope that as readers, you will become a gatekeeper for life in your community.

Shimada Kenji, who takes pictures of capybaras every week and posts them on SNS, on February 1st, at the indoor facility "Hapisjan" in Asuwa Park, Fukui City, Fukui Prefecture
There is a man in Fukui who takes a photo of the capybara at the indoor facility "Hapisjan" in Fukui City's Asuwa Park Amusement Park every week and posts it on Instagram.
The posts are filled with a variety of thumbnail images, such as a man yawning with his mouth wide open and a man lying down with his head on his hands.
The followers number more than 10,000 both in Japan and overseas, and they are helping to spread the charm of Hapisjan and Kappabara to many people.
⇒Kudou Shizuka posts traditional vegetables from Fukui Prefecture on Instagram
The man is a company employee who lives in the city, Shimada Kenji (38).
He began posting on social media (SNS) from March 2021.
The capybara is the world's largest rodent, and is known for its swimming skills, which it uses to splash water between its fingers.
Since opening to the public in 2018, Hapisjan has been raising three individuals, one male and two females, and is able to observe and feed them regularly.
Shimada-san met capybara 5 or 6 years ago.
He was shocked when he saw a video of a capybara relaxing in a hot spring and thought, "What kind of animal is this?"
He was drawn to the gentle and affectionate expressions that were almost human.
After that, I heard that it was raised at Hapijan and was looking forward to seeing it up close.
I started taking photos seriously about three years ago, when I bought a single-lens reflex camera.
I use it to capture the cute appearance of the capybara, and I don't miss any shutter chances such as shaking its body and cutting water like a drill.
The number of posts on Instagram is about 830, and I look back and think "I took a lot of these."
I remember meeting Shimada-san when I was walking by, and the male Yamato and Kuni would come close and make a "kyu-kyu" sound.
Meanwhile, Shimada-san's love for capybaras deepens as well, saying "they're cute and I'm happy."
Through SNS, I enjoy exchanging the best shots with people all over Japan who love capybaras every month.
Shima-da, who travels to a zoo in a neighboring prefecture to see capybaras, said with a smile, "I want to continue filming and posting from Asuwa in my hometown from now on."

Toba City to double child-rearing allowance payments, seeks repayment - Ise Newspaper
【鳥羽】鳥羽市は10日、令和3年度の子育て世帯生活支援特別給付金(その他世帯分)について、11世帯12人に合計60萬円の誤支給があったと発表した。
The city is asking the recipients to return the money, while apologizing to them and explaining the circumstances.
According to the city, the error was discovered on January 27, 2021, when the guardian of a child who had received past payments pointed out the error.
It was confirmed that among 79 households and 182 people who were the recipients of the subsidy in the same year, 11 households and 12 people received the subsidy twice on July 20, 2020.
The city pays a benefit of 50,000 yen per child to households exempt from residential tax, targeting children up to high school age.

The city had received data on the target children from the contracted computer company, but the staff mistakenly added high school students to the data, thinking that they were not included, and paid twice.
The person in charge of the city's childcare support room said, "We will take this seriously, and we will do our best to prevent this from happening again by rechecking the data and restoring trust."
Soft tennis tournament held every three years, All-Japan women's team selection at Yokkaichi Dome - Ise Newspaper
[Players who are practicing for the tournament the day before = at Yokkaichi Dome in Yokkaichi City, Mino-ku]

The 37th Dunlop Cup All-Japan Women's Team Selection Soft Tennis Tournament (organized by the All-Japan Women's Industrial Association Strengthening Committee, with support from the Ise Shimbun and others) will be held on the 11th and 12th, after a three-year hiatus, at the Yokkaichi Dome in Yokkaichi City, Hida-cho.
The tournament will feature 24 teams from 23 organizations, including the national league teams, as well as industrial and university teams.
The tournament has been held annually since 1986 with the aim of improving the level of play before the Japan League opens, and since 1998, the Yokkaichi Dome has been the venue.
It was cancelled for two years in a row due to the impact of COVID-19 from 2021, and this year's tournament will be held for the first time in three years.

The 24 teams will be divided into 8 blocks, and the first league (preliminary round) will be held from 9am on the 11th, followed by the second league (semi-finals) of 12 matches from around 3pm on the 12th, and the remaining matches and ranking matches from 9am on the 12th.
From Mie Prefecture, two teams from the Mie Prefectural Selection will participate in the tournament, aiming to enter the top 8 in the Mie High School and the Kagoshima National Selection this fall.
Both days, they will not impose a limit on the number of spectators, but will implement basic measures against infectious diseases.
It is a free entrance park.
The chairman of the Mie Prefecture Soft Tennis Association, Amano Haruo, said, "It's a great opportunity to see top-level players play. Please come and watch."

植物研究の先人紹介 早池峰山採集資料も 市総合文化財センター企画展【花巻】|Iwanichi Online 岩手日日新聞社

An exhibition of the pioneers who laid the foundation for the study of plants in Mount Hayachine, known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, entitled "People who introduced the flowers of Hayachine Peak - A brief history of the study of plants in Hayachine Peak" is being held at the city's comprehensive cultural property center in Ohasama, Hanamaki, until the 12th.
The exhibition introduces the precious specimens and other materials collected by the predecessors, and the footprints of the predecessors who were involved in the plant research of Mount Hayachine.

The study of plants on Mount Hayachine began with Russian plant researcher Karl Johann Maximovich (1827-91), who came to Japan at the end of the Edo period, and with Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who was born in Shiwa and collected plants under Maximovich's guidance.
Maximowitch, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country for foreigners, asked Sugawa to collect plants and continued his research for three years with Yokohama and Nagasaki as his base.

Even after Makino returned to Russia, Tsukawa continued to support his research, and this led to the publication of the "Himekazakura", "Nambotouwachisou", and "Miyamayamabukishouma", which are unique to Mount Hayachine.

After that, the modern plant taxonomist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cerastium katoana", "Draba japonica" in 1903 (Meiji 36) based on the collection of local researchers, and "Arenaria katoana" in 1905 (Meiji 38) which he discovered and named himself on Mount Hayachine.
From the exhibition materials, it is clear that many researchers have discovered valuable alpine plants.

Also introduced are Shinozaki Masaoki (1874-1948), who was the principal of Hanaokamochi Elementary School and conducted plant research while participating in the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Yokawa Nanoru (1914-1988), who was a teacher at the Tamagawa Museum in Ohhasama-machi and participated in the publication of "Plants of Otsuok

Yoshida Shunpei, a researcher at the center, said, "Each of the plants on Mount Hayachine has a background of many studies and connections with people. It is possible to connect researchers from all over the country with each other."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, with the first chapter focusing on the faith and history of Mount Hayachine, and the second chapter featuring the research of German geologist Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), who laid the foundation for Japanese geology, and other researchers, with a spotlight on the geological features of Mount Hayachine.

Against the backdrop of the introduction of renewable energy and the setting of goals, the second decarbonization promotion council was held at Amami Airport | Society-Economy | Nankai Nippo
讨论推进脱碳化的促进会议=9日在奄美市笠利町举行

In order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (Kasari-cho, Amami City), the "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Aoki Shun, Chief of the Construction Section of the Ōshima Subprefectural Office, 13 members) held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members, including online, attended.
The committee discussed the setting of decarbonization goals and exchanged opinions on the introduction of renewable energy, with solar power generation as the main source.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 46% or more by 2030 (compared to 2013) in order to achieve "carbon neutrality" by 2050, which is the goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to zero.
In response to this, the council held its first meeting last November, and is aiming to plan and prepare for the other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting was held in the same way as the first, with the exception of the opening.
According to Ando, chairman of the meeting, the meeting confirmed the greenhouse gas emissions of the airport.
The meeting was held to set goals and introduce renewable energy in accordance with the guidelines of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism.
According to the distribution materials, the CO2 emissions from the airport facilities and vehicles in the fiscal year 2013, which serves as the benchmark, is 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, the CO2 emissions from the lighting and air conditioning of seven facilities such as the airport terminal building account for 1321 tons, or about 90%, followed by the airport lighting at 84 tons and airport vehicles at 71 tons.
The council will discuss reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.

Opening event deepens understanding of "Sakasama Real Estate" at Talk Session and other events = On the 8th, an event to deepen understanding of "Sakasama Real Estate" was held in a well-known town.

The opening event for the Okinoerabu branch of the real estate website service "Sakasama Real Estate" was held on the 8th at the well-known community space "entaku" in the famous town of China-cho, where they visualized the thoughts of people who want to challenge things like borrowing vacant houses and vacant shops, and called for landlords.
Through a talk session, the operating company explained the overview of the service.

Takayuki Okubo, the representative director of Tuginohaba (Rishiri district, Hokkaido) who is in charge of the branch office operation said, "If we can create a movement and flow to attract people to the island as a whole by doing this in Okinoerabu Island,"

Sakasama Real Estate is a system that is the opposite of the usual real estate procedures, where the information of people who want to borrow is disclosed to the landlord, and if they agree, they conclude a contract on their own.

As a real-world experiment to discover potential vacant houses and build relationships through them, the service is operated by the company On-Co (headquarters in Mie Prefecture), which began the service in June 2020.
This is the 7th branch office to open in Kyushu.
This is the first time in the country to open a branch on a remote island.
About 20 people, including On-Co staff, staff from the town hall in Kaminokuni, a well-known town in Okazaki, and residents of the area, participated in the event.

Representative Director Okubo explained the circumstances surrounding the opening of the branch, saying, "I thought that if we could make use of vacant houses and vacant shops, the town and the island would become even more vibrant as the movement to attract people from the mainland becomes more active."
"I want to help connect people who own properties on the island and people who want to do something with them with us, and to help them move forward with their projects, one by one."

On―Co's Mizutani Yusuke representative pointed out the necessity of discussing how the locals want to develop the area, who they want to attract, and what criteria they will use to select properties, as they take on the operation of the vacant houses.
He called on island residents to participate in discussions and provide information, saying, "The more people are connected, the more information will be gathered."

I've been using a Doshisha made office chair (jump up armrest) for 4~5 years, but the synthetic leather has deteriorated and is now dull, so I'm considering purchasing a non-synthetic leather jump up armrest chair.

The hardness of the jump up armrests is different on the left and right, and it is heavier to lift up on the left and lighter on the right, so the armrests are not easy to use (there is no adjustment method).

The seat feels hard and uncomfortable (is the springiness weak?
) The backrest part of the competition mesh is harder and thinner than other mesh chairs, so it hurts your back.

I felt that it was a good fit for my back, but other than that, I felt that it was a low satisfaction product, and I felt that it was a product that was not worth the price.
